snippet.textDisplay:
While the intent here is to give a lesson on exponential and logistic growth as general phenomena, with epidemics as a timely case study, there are a few notes worth adding when it comes to epidemics themselves. Probably the most important, mentioned only as a small on-screen note, is that these models should account for the amount of time someone with the virus remains infectious. Those who recover (or die) are no longer able to spread it, and so don't factor into the growth equation. The faster the growth, the less this matters, since at each point on the curve most people with the virus will have only contracted it recently, but especially in the long run or with slower growth, any realistic model has to consider this. The other factor, which I was hesitant to even get into here, is the extent to which reported cases reflect real cases.

Generalizing away from epidemics, though, the key upshot is to be aware of phenomena where the rate of growth is proportional to the size of the thing growing. Compound interest, technological progress, population growth, and many other things fit this pattern, and it's shocking how bad our intuitions can be at recognizing what it means.
snippet.textOriginal:
While the intent here is to give a lesson on exponential and logistic growth as general phenomena, with epidemics as a timely case study, there are a few notes worth adding when it comes to epidemics themselves.  Probably the most important, mentioned only as a small on-screen note, is that these models should account for the amount of time someone with the virus remains infectious.  Those who recover (or die) are no longer able to spread it, and so don't factor into the growth equation.  The faster the growth, the less this matters, since at each point on the curve most people with the virus will have only contracted it recently, but especially in the long run or with slower growth, any realistic model has to consider this.  The other factor, which I was hesitant to even get into here, is the extent to which reported cases reflect real cases.

Generalizing away from epidemics, though, the key upshot is to be aware of phenomena where the rate of growth is proportional to the size of the thing growing.  Compound interest, technological progress, population growth, and many other things fit this pattern, and it's shocking how bad our intuitions can be at recognizing what it means.

snippet.textDisplay:
It is interesting to see how the world has reacted to this issue with respect to self-preservation.
The sound of the kookaburras laughing outside makes me wonder if they know something that we don't.
Fear and paranoia are like a virus within itself that destroys all logic and reasoning.
It would be interesting to know the effects on all the other species as it appears that they are well protected.
I have always enjoyed statistical analysis as a form of predicting the future.
I would like to see further results based on the rise in population and the effects on toxicity and the destruction of the environment.

snippet.textDisplay:
This is a helpful, informative video, but here's something I don't understand:

At 5:01, you say that a logistic curve levels out close to the entire population (meaning everyone eventually gets infected). But at 6:30, you say that if the growth factor is 1, that could mean you're at the inflection point, which could mean the total number of cases is about twice the current number of cases.

First of all, I don't understand why we should expect radial symmetry around the inflection point, even in the "keep going until everyone gets infected" model, but I'm assuming there's a mathematical justification that you didn't get into (you didn't say there's radial symmetry, but you're assuming the inflection point happens when the slope is 1 and that the height is half of the eventual height, which sounds a lot like radial symmetry).

But more importantly, if you're not assuming that everyone eventually gets infected, then what model are you using? Under your model, how is the spread of the disease eventually stopped short of the entire world population contracting it, and what justifies the assumption that the number of infected people follows a logistic curve, or that properties of the logistic curve that we got from the "everyone-eventually-gets-it" model (i.e. radial symmetry) still hold in whatever other model we're using?
snippet.textOriginal:

At 5:01, you say that a logistic curve levels out close to the entire population (meaning everyone eventually gets infected). But at 6:30, you say that if the growth factor is 1, that could mean you're at the inflection point, which could mean the total number of cases is about twice the current number of cases.

First of all, I don't understand why we should expect radial symmetry around the inflection point, even in the "keep going until everyone gets infected" model, but I'm assuming there's a mathematical justification that you didn't get into (you didn't say there's radial symmetry, but you're assuming the inflection point happens when the slope is 1 and that the height is half of the eventual height, which sounds a lot like radial symmetry).  

But more importantly, if you're not assuming that everyone eventually gets infected, then what model are you using? Under your model, how is the spread of the disease eventually stopped short of the entire world population contracting it, and what justifies the assumption that the number of infected people follows a logistic curve, or that properties of the logistic curve that we got from the "everyone-eventually-gets-it" model (i.e. radial symmetry) still hold in whatever other model we're using?

snippet.textDisplay:
I have a question.

The equation
N’(t)= c (1-N) N
( where N has been divided by Pop to rescale from the video version )
Seems to yield to a function that converges to 1 always, ie this model predicts everybody will get sick eventually, which obviously is unrealistic.

Is this correct?

snippet.textDisplay: I can’t understand why we can’t have a massive ramp up of production of N95 masks and give them out to everyone.  If 80%-90% wear them it would drastically cut down the transmission rates of the virus.  Consider masks, hand sanitizers, etc. as war production as we did in WWII when we enlisted entire industries in the effort to rapidly produce military supplies.
snippet.textOriginal: I can’t understand why we can’t have a massive ramp up of production of N95 masks and give them out to everyone.  If 80%-90% wear them it would drastically cut down the transmission rates of the virus. snippet.textDisplay: In the video, he said the growth rate was 15 percent at the time her recorded the video on March 6. As of today, one week later, if you calculate the growth rate  you get X^7• 21,000= 139,000. If you solve for x, x=1.30 which is a 30 percent increase in the number of cases daily. That means, dispute our efforts to quarantine and self isolation, we are no where near the inflection point and are actually spreading the virus at a higher rate than a week ago.
snippet.textOriginal: In the video, he said the growth rate was 15 percent at the time her recorded the video on March 6. As of today, one week later, if you calculate the growth rate  you get X^7• 21,000= 139,000. If you solve for x, x=1.30 which is a 30 percent increase in the number of cases daily. That means, dispute our efforts to quarantine and self isolation, we are no where near the inflection point and are actually spreading the virus at a higher rate than a week ago.

snippet.textDisplay: The panic and hysteria created seems to be making the problem worse. Countless doctors have now come out and said that if you’re not very old and don’t have a serious pre-existing medical condition than yes it might hit you a bit harder than the normal flu but you’re certainly not going to die from it. Cue ridiculous  headlines from newspapers “we’re doomed”!!!! There are literally thousands of other diseases, infections, parasites you could possibly get that could be potentially deadly and all of a sudden we have to stop literally everything for this specific virus. You could understand if it was a deadly disease for everybody or perhaps a chemical attack of some sort like anthrax but this is insane. Just goes to show how much power the media and social media had over people these days. I am saying it’s not serious? No. Is it serious for 98% of people? No. People panic buying toilet roll as well?! Didn’t realise it induced vomiting and diarrhoea lol
snippet.textOriginal: The panic and hysteria created seems to be making the problem worse. Cue ridiculous  headlines from newspapers “we’re doomed”!!!! There are literally thousands of other diseases, infections, parasites you could possibly get that could be potentially deadly and all of a sudden we have to stop literally everything for this specific virus. You could understand if it was a deadly disease for everybody or perhaps a chemical attack of some sort like anthrax but this is insane. snippet.textDisplay:
I learnt more about Coronavirus from this maths video than I have from health experts.

I work in Psychology, and it's interesting how the maths here is completely intuitive for me working with stats, and I've been trying to say to people for a while now that the new cases per day are not a good measure of how well or poorly a country is doing.
snippet.textOriginal:
I learnt more about Coronavirus from this maths video than I have from health experts. 

I work in Psychology, and it's interesting how the maths here is completely intuitive for me working with stats, and I've been trying to say to people for a while now that the new cases per day are not a good measure of how well or poorly a country is doing.

snippet.textDisplay: it's a good real life example of how to apply math to a problem, but fortunately we can influence this curve by proper hygiene and good habits (staying away from each other)
